title: The Painful Eyeball
author: Alexander Kin Chiang Chiu
keyPoints: Always check pupil response and visual acuity to give you useful clues to the diagnosis
Consider whether you need to check corneal sensation before instilling topical anaesthesia
Refrain from prescribing topical anaesthetics as a treatment from the eye casualty
Don't rely on the referring party's examination, always ask the right questions to rule out serious pathology

answers.text: Normal or mildly reduced visual acuity

q2.text: Are the pupils normal and reactive?

answers.text: Fixed mid-dilated pupil with hard eye

q4.text: What is the nature of the pain?

q5.text: Any corneal involvement or anterior chamber inflammation?

q6.text: Is the pain worse with eye movement?

q7.text: Any history of trauma or foreign body?

q8.text: Any fluorescein staining of the cornea?

q9.text: Any proptosis or restriction of eye movements?

q10.text: Is the sclera injected or does phenylephrine blanch the vessels?

q11.text: Any recent eye surgery or procedures?

acute_glaucoma.text: ACUTE ANGLE-CLOSURE GLAUCOMA: Immediate IOP lowering - topical timolol, brimonidine, pilocarpine. IV acetazolamide 500mg. Analgesia and antiemetics. Emergency ophthalmology referral.

optic_neuropathy.text: OPTIC NEUROPATHY: Urgent assessment for cause. Check for GCA if age >50. MRI brain and orbits. Urgent ophthalmology and neurology referral.

anterior_uveitis.text: ANTERIOR UVEITIS: Topical steroids (prednisolone 1% hourly) and cycloplegics (cyclopentolate 1%). Same-day ophthalmology referral. Investigate underlying cause.

corneal_infection.text: CORNEAL INFECTION: Corneal scraping for culture. Intensive topical antibiotics (hourly). Urgent ophthalmology referral. Admit if severe or poor compliance.

posterior_pathology.text: POSTERIOR PATHOLOGY: Dilated fundus examination. Consider posterior uveitis, endophthalmitis. Urgent ophthalmology referral for assessment.

orbital_pathology.text: ORBITAL PATHOLOGY: CT orbits urgently. Consider orbital cellulitis, thyroid eye disease, orbital tumor. Urgent ophthalmology referral.

optic_neuritis.text: OPTIC NEURITIS: MRI brain and orbits with gadolinium. Pain typically worse with eye movement. Urgent neurology and ophthalmology referral.

scleritis.text: SCLERITIS: Systemic NSAIDs or steroids may be needed. Investigate for underlying autoimmune disease. Urgent ophthalmology referral.

episcleritis.text: EPISCLERITIS: Topical NSAIDs or mild steroids. Usually self-limiting. Routine ophthalmology follow-up if recurrent.

trauma_assessment.text: TRAUMA ASSESSMENT: Examine for corneal foreign body, abrasion, or penetrating injury. Remove superficial FB if safe. Topical antibiotic and follow-up.

corneal_abrasion.text: CORNEAL ABRASION: Topical antibiotic, cycloplegic for comfort. Large abrasions may need padding. Follow-up in 24-48 hours.

dry_eye_assessment.text: DRY EYE SYNDROME: Artificial tears, lid hygiene. Consider underlying causes. Ophthalmology referral if severe or not responding to treatment.

post_surgical_pain.text: POST-SURGICAL PAIN: Assess for complications - endophthalmitis, wound leak, raised IOP. Urgent ophthalmology review if concerning features.

neuralgic_pain.text: NEURALGIC PAIN: Consider trigeminal neuralgia, atypical facial pain. May need neurology referral if typical neuralgic features present.
